title: Rare ‘deep-diving’ whales spotted off Mass. coast
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: New England Aquarium spotted three rare True's beaked whales 130 miles off Cape Cod in mid-October.
The whales were located in the Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument during an aerial survey.
The survey also recorded more than 700 marine animals including seven fin whales and 402 common dolphins.

title: One of Mass.’s most expensive towns launches plan to combat antisemitism after 3 swastika incidents
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Weston, Massachusetts, initiates a plan to combat antisemitism after three swastika incidents in local schools.
Weston Public Schools partners with the Anti Defamation League and police for a response guide after incidents.
A new curriculum response, vetting by various committees, aims for spring introduction to combat antisemitism.

title: Trevor Story discussed why he didn’t opt out of Red Sox contract
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Trevor Story confirmed he will not opt out of his Red Sox contract, choosing to stay for the final two years.
Story cited his commitment to the team and the Red Sox's potential as reasons for staying, despite past injuries.
In 2025, Story had a healthy season, batting .263 with 25 home runs and 31 stolen bases for the Red Sox.

title: Massport releases statement on FAA announcement, says Logan Airport will be impacted
author: John Waller
bullets: Massport confirms Logan Airport is among 40 airports affected by a 10% reduction in air traffic due to a government shutdown.
The FAA's changes will begin on November 7, potentially causing delays and cancellations at Logan Airport.
Passengers are advised by Massport to check with airlines for updates before traveling to Logan Airport.

title: License plate reader cameras in Brookline? Readers say it’s a bad idea.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Brookline Select Board pauses agreement for police access to license plate reader data due to privacy concerns.
66% of 298 surveyed readers oppose license plate reader cameras, fearing privacy invasion and questioning crime deterrence.
Chestnut Hill Realty proposed cameras to address theft; debate erupted between privacy concerns and crime reduction support.

title: John Mulaney, Chelsea Handler, Marc Maron, Jay Pharoah on bill for huge New England comedy fest
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Lil Rhody Laugh Riot comedy festival in Providence features John Mulaney, Chelsea Handler, Marc Maron, Jay Pharoah, Andrew Schulz.
The festival runs from March 26-29, 2026, with events at Veterans Memorial Auditorium and other local venues.
Tickets for the festival go on sale November 7, with more performers to join closer to the event.

title: Former Celtics guard Tony Allen arrested on drug charges
author: The Associated Press
bullets: Former Celtics guard Tony Allen, 43, was arrested on drug possession charges in Poinsett County, Arkansas.
A traffic stop revealed Allen with marijuana, while a car search found cocaine in a cigarette box.
Allen, implicated in an NBA health insurance fraud, is on supervised probation after a guilty plea in 2023.

title: A pickup’s persistent plastic pan problems
author: John Paul
bullets: Ford F-150 owner frustrated with repeated plastic oil pan leaks, seeks metal replacement costing $200.
Ford dealer requires 10 hours to replace the metal oil pan; warranty only covers the plastic pan replacement.
Reader considers selling the truck due to expensive repairs and questions Ford's vehicle design decisions.

title: Patriots get bad news with injuries ahead of Bucs matchup
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots' Kayshon Boutte, Rhamondre Stevenson, and Garrett Bradbury did not practice Wednesday due to various injuries.
Rookies TreVeyon Henderson and Terrell Jennings may get more game time if Stevenson and Boutte are unavailable.
Buccaneers also face injuries with key players like Chris Godwin and Bucky Irving missing Wednesday's practice.

title: Boston youth baseball coach pleads not guilty to drug trafficking charge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Bryan Mejia, 31, a Boston Athletic Academy coach, pleaded not guilty to felony fentanyl trafficking charges in Roxbury court.
Mejia allegedly sold over 10 grams of fentanyl to an undercover officer on October 19, facing up to 20 years in prison.
The coach, previously with Fredericksburg Nationals, was released on personal recognizance and will return to court on December 1.
